awd_titl_txt: STTR Phase I:  An intuitive and tactile quantum mechanical molecular modeling tool for instruction of chemistry students
awd_abstract_narration:
This STTR Phase I project is focused on development of a hands-on instructional tool based on interactive molecular dynamics simulations that will engage organic chemistry students in the study of chemical reactions.  There is currently a need for educational tools that teach chemistry more effectively to young American students, as well as inspire them to pursue careers in the physical sciences.  Because chemistry is the study of objects (atoms and molecules) too small to experience directly, an unusually large amount of abstract thinking is required to learn the subject.  This can present a problem that can be very difficult for students to overcome.  The fun, game-like, educational tool that is the focus of this STTR project will not only offer the student the ability to induce a chemical reaction by hand but also to see how the molecule behaves while the reaction is taking place, allowing the student to gain chemical intuition in a way that is virtually unprecedented.  Ultimately, this software is expected to serve as a powerful tool for chemistry, biology, and materials science researchers as well, and as a result it should have a positive impact on many of the important challenges facing the world today.

The product of this STTR project will be a tactile and interactive instructional computer tool along with a set of computer laboratory exercises that will more effectively teach organic chemistry and chemical intuition.  The key advantages this technology has over existing chemistry simulation tools are that 1) accurate simulations of very complex molecular interactions are computed in real-time in response to a student's input and involvement in the reaction environment, and 2) a 3D haptic or no-touch input device allows the student to manipulate the evolving chemical system during the simulation.  Graphical processing units (consumer graphics cards primarily used for video gaming) and redesigned computer algorithms for first principles quantum chemistry modeling serve as the enabling technologies for the instructional tool.  The main tasks to be performed during the STTR Phase I project are 1) development of a user interface and 2) development of a set of organic chemistry laboratory exercises that render the technology suitable for educational applications.  In addition, although the underlying software technology (including the input device interface) is advanced enough to allow instruction of nearly all organic chemistry concepts, further development will continue in order to improve the efficiency and expand the capabilities of the software.

por.por_cntn:
This Small Business Technology Transfer (STTR) project demonstrated the feasibility of developing an computer-based educational tool for effective instruction of organic chemistry students based on tactile, interactive molecular dynamics.

Because chemistry is the study of abstract objects, atoms and molecules, too small to experience directly, it presents a challenge for the student that can be very difficult to overcome. Although an important part of a chemist’s training, abstract thinking can be difficult for young students to master. In line with the Chinese proverb, I hear and I forget; I see and I remember; I do and I understand, chemistry curricula universally emphasize hands-on laboratory exercises to help students do and understand. Molecular simulation, though invaluable to almost all successful research programs, is generally not considered a hands-on form of instruction.

But what if the simulation were interactive? Interactive ab initio MD not only offers the student the ability to induce a chemical reaction by hand but also to see how the molecule behaves while the reaction is taking place, allowing the student to gain chemical intuition in a way that is virtually unprecedented. It would not only be hands-on but would also relieve some of the abstract thinking that would otherwise be required. 

Our computer-based educational tool will allow students to conduct “hands-on” computer experiments at the molecular level and thus develop lasting insights into reaction chemistry that cannot be obtained through studying theory alone.  The key differences between existing chemistry simulation tools and the one proposed for this effort are that in the proposed software, 1) accurate ab initio molecular dynamics simulations of very complex molecular interactions are computed in real-time in response to a student’s input and involvement in the reaction environment, 2) a 3D haptic or no-touch input device allows the student to manipulate the evolving chemical system in 3D space.  If a haptic input device is used the student will receive tactile feedback proportional to the restoring forces that govern how the molecule would respond to the force applied by the student, allowing the student to gain a better understanding of the various forces in a chemical system.

We have successfully completed all proposed tasks. We have designed a good scheme for rendering the molecular system so that the student can interpret visually how the system behaves during interaction. We have also established a systematic process for setting up simulations to be used for student instruction. Our newly developed user interface is a significantly more flexible framework for performing interactive simulations and developing applications. We completed development of a set of exercises designed to augment teaching of the SN1, SN2, E1, and E2 reaction mechanisms, which are some of the most important and fundamental reactions in the field of organic chemistry. We have demonstrated our educational tool to students, educators, and education technology experts using this lesson. In doing so, we obtained helpful feedback on how to improve our educational tool for successful commercialization, and at the same time stimulated a great deal of excitement about the future of chemical education. Finally, in addition to supporting haptic devices, our educational tool now also supports the Leap Motion controller, a more affordable option for user input that works well with virtual reality systems now hitting the market. Our new user interface is being developed in a way that will make support of virtual reality systems as well as many other alternative user input devices straightforward to add in the relatively near future. The success of our completed Phase I project should provide a very solid platform for a successful Phase II project and commercially prosperous educational tool for chemistry.
